issues.description: The problem statement requires a method named checkOrderReady() (UML and textual instructions request orderMeal to call checkOrderReady()). The solution class SealSaloon.java does not implement checkOrderReady(); instead it implements a method named processOrders() and orderMeal() calls processOrders(). This is a structural mismatch in the public API the problem describes versus the solution implementation and can confuse students about which method to implement (and how their orderMeal should call it).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's public API match the problem specification: either rename the solution method processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), or add a public checkOrderReady() method that delegates to processOrders(). Ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady() as requested in the problem statement so students see the expected method name and behavior.

issues.description: The problem statement specifies a method named checkOrderReady() (UML and textual description) that should be called to attempt serving queued orders. In the solution implementation the same behavior is implemented in a method named processOrders(), and orderMeal() calls processOrders(). This name divergence (checkOrderReady vs processOrders) creates a mapping mismatch: students reading the problem will look for/implement checkOrderReady(), while the reference solution uses a different name, increasing cognitive load and causing confusion about which method implements the required behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Use the same identifier in both problem and implementation. Rename solution method processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), or add a public checkOrderReady() wrapper that delegates to processOrders(), so the method name matches the problem statement and students can map requirements to implementation directly.
